post_text: I built this integration. I thought I knew the risks. We pushed the Aggregator service. Green tests validated our client’s logic against the spec. Then P99 latency instantly doubled. Users across three regions started seeing timeouts. Logs flooded with deserialization errors—“expected string, found array.” My heart sank. I checked our client generation. It was flawless. I assumed the Product team strictly adhered to the v2 contract definition, believing the core metadata_tag field structure was fixed. The contradiction was painful. Their recent internal refactor, designed for efficiency, silently modified the field’s type. They changed it from a nullable string to a nullable array of strings, thinking an empty array was equivalent to a null string for compatibility. They owned the source; we owned the failure. 🤦 The ownership gap exploded under load. The Moral 👇
lesson_extracted: True API compatibility depends on the consumer’s expectations, not the producer’s interpretation of null.
